indicators.justification:
UAE have 52 gas emission monitoring stations in 2019 (1) according to a dataset published in the official open data portal. However there is no dataset published on gas emission in the country. There is only gas emission data in reports by the Ministry of Climate Change and Environment (2), and the Environment Agency of Abu Dhabi (3).

## References

1- https://bayanat.ae/en/Data?themeid=21
2- https://www.moccae.gov.ae/assets/download/fa2f8dd4/Air%20Emissions%20Inventory%20Report.pdf.aspx
3- https://www.ead.gov.ae/storage/EAD5726_GREENHOUSE%20GAS%20INVENTORY%20REPORT_ENGLISH_FOR%20WEB.pdf

evidence.title: GREENHOUSE GAS INVENTORY by Abu Dhabi
UAE National Air Emissions Inventory Project by MCCE

indicators.justification:
By 2020 there were 49 nature reserves in the UAE, the country is  committed to protecting and managing the rich biodiversity of the state and prevent the extinction of threatened species (1). However there is only literature published online about biodiversity and endangered species (2). The research found no evidence of database including such data.

1- https://u.ae/en/information-and-services/environment-and-energy/environmental-protection/nature-reserves 
2- https://u.ae/en/about-the-uae/leaving-no-one-behind/15lifeonland

indicators.justification:
The research did not find any climate change data available in UAE. The only dataset available in the official UAE Open Data portal is a dataset of customer centers for Ministry of Climate Change and Environment by emirate and geographical location (1). Official UAE portal include a section on climate change and UAE response to climate change, however there is no data only few reports and general articles (2).

indicators.justification:
According to the FNC UAE election committee, the candidate is obligated to submit an account statement for the donations he receives to the Emirate Committee, on the form prepared for this (an account statement for the donations received by the candidate) (1). So if there is any data available it could be only offline at the Emirate committee.

indicators.justification:
TDRA policy defines open data as data that anyone can use, reuse, distribute or share with others without technical, financial or legal restrictions. (1) In UAE a data hackathon is organized every year since 2018, show the strong support for open data in UAE by the Government, even if there is almost no information published online on created applications in these Hackathons. (2)

## References

1- https://www.tdra.gov.ae/en/open-data/open-data-policy.aspx
2- https://hackathon.ae/

There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by the private sector.
Government support for data reuse involves data challenges.
Government support for data reuse involves hackathons.
Government support for data reuse involves communication and community building efforts.
Government support for data reuse involves running information sessions on how to use particular datasets, or how to reuse government data in general.
Government support for data reuse involves the release of funding schemes

responses.response_text: Support assessed is at national level.
responses.subquestion_text: How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the support assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
UAE have an active open data initiative since 2012 (1) led by the Federal Competitiveness and Statistics Authority (2) (FCSA) on the country level, with a national open data portal : bayanat.ae (3).

UAE adopted an open data policy (4) and a set of guidelines (5) facilitating an effective open data practice.

responses.response_text: There is evidence of an active government-led open government data initiative.
responses.subquestion_text: Has there been any form of government-led open government data initiative during the study period?
There is a government team in place supporting open data activities.
There is an allocated budget for open data activities.
There is a well-maintained open data portal.
There is guidance and support for government publication of open data.
Senior political leaders back the open data initiative.

responses.response_text: The open data initiative covers much of the national government, and there are similar initiatives in many sub-national areas.
responses.subquestion_text: How widely does this, or similar, open data initiatives apply?

indicators.justification:
Dubai (1) and Abu Dhabi (2) are example of regional government having their own data law and policy.

responses.response_text: There is evidence of sustained and institutionalized capability to manage data.

There is evidence of local governments having open data initiatives.

responses.response_text: The examples given represent common practice: many cities or regions have comparable capacity to effectively manage data.
responses.subquestion_text: How widespread are local capacities to effectively manage data?

indicators.justification:
The Telecommunications and Digital Government Regulatory Authority provide as part of its virtual academy a set of courses including among others introduction to data, data science, big data etc (1). Courses are available to anyone in the UAE not only to civil servants.

There are also the UAE Hackathons, launched in 2018 and organized yearly in all UAE Emirates (2). Hackathons are organized in Universities and provides training, workshop and seminars for participants to reinforce their knowledge with data in addition to the support of couches and data experts.

There are others training programs such as Maaref (3), and Al-Marid (4) which both provides training to civil servants in data related topics such as Statistical analysis, knowledge management...etc.

Digital Dubai offer a range of educational and training resources going from from short workshops to a full-fledged MSC degree in Data Analytics (5).

1- https://academy.tdra.gov.ae/index.php?lang=EN

4- https://al-mawrid.ae/
5- https://www.digitaldubai.ae/data/upgrade-your-skills

indicators.justification: The research did not find any political integrity data interoperable across different political integrity datasets, or other datasets associated with relevant information flows in UAE.

responses.response_text: The datasets do not share common identifiers.
responses.subquestion_text: There is evidence that datasets share common identifiers.
The key datasets for this theme share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The different political integrity datasets use common identifiers for public officials.
Lobbying data and political finance data share common identifiers for lobbyist clients and party and campaign donors.
Lobbying registers and public consultation data use common identifiers for regulations.
Asset declarations and political finance disclosures share common identifiers for interests, assets, and liabilities.
The various datasets share common identifiers for legal persons associated with donations, interests, assets, liabilities, and lobbying activities.
The key datasets for the political integrity and company information modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and land modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public finance modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public procurement modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

indicators.justification:
Companies creation in UAE is governed by the federal law 2 of 2015 (1). Significant changes are made to this law through the UAE Federal Decree Law 26 of 2020, which came into force from January 2, 2021 (2).

There are however separate company register in each emirate of the UAE such as Abu Dhabi Global Market public register (3) and Dubai international finance center public register (4).

indicators.justification:
There is no legal framework for consistent data management and publication on the federal level, however there is Abu Dhabi Government Data Management Standards (1) and policy (2).

indicators.justification:
Dubai Emirate have Law No. 26 of 2015 Regulating Data Dissemination and Exchange in the Emirate of Dubai. (1)

On the federal level, UAE have the smart data framework (2)(3) a key element in the UAE National Plan for Smart Government released on February 2019. From the objectives of this framework "Ensure efficient data sharing between government entities". The framework detailed in two documents : Principles & standards, and implementation guide; provides a detailed guidelines for data sharing between government entities and between third parties.

## References
1- https://www.smartdubai.ae/docs/default-source/dubai-data/data-dissemination-and-exchange-in-the-emirate-of-dubai-law_2015.pdf?sfvrsn=46ac2296_6

indicators.justification:
UAE Constitution gives citizens a general right to privacy, and provisions of the Federal Law No. 5 of 1985: The Civil Code as amended by Federal Law No. 1 of 1987 (1) and the Federal Law No. 3 of 1987: The Penal Code (2) are also relevant when considering privacy related issues. Otherwise there is no legal framework for protection of personal data.

Dubai International Finance Center (DIFC) have its own data protection law since July 2020 (3).

On the federal level the Telecommunications and Digital Government Regulatory Authority (TDRA) provides an open data policy which allows access to data that can be used by developers, researchers, media, and the public (1). However there are a government Data policy in Abu Dhabi (2), and an open data policy in Dubai (3).

UAE started since 2011 publishing its federal budget as open data (1) however there is no legal obligation to publish it in open or closed format in the federal level.

indicators.justification:
UAE have elections only related to Federal National Council (FNC). According to UAE constitution article 69 (1) an Emirate is free to determine the method of selection of its representatives in the FNC. Only after 2006, UAE started organizing elections to the FNC since 2006 by virtue of the Resolution No. 3 of 2006, issued by H. H. Sheikh Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan, President of the UAE (2).

There is no relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on campaign and party finance. According to the election committee, candidate should provide its Emirate with a report of campaign finance, however there is no legal obligation or follow up process (3).

2- https://u.ae/en/about-the-uae/the-uae-government/the-federal-national-council-
3- https://uaenec.ae/ar/Candidature/Campaigning

indicators.justification:
The research did not find any relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data generated through and about public consultation on rulemaking in UAE. However The country is actively publishing public consultation active, planned and closed (1). Each consultation include start, end date and description, in addition to contact information for some of them and survey results for closed ones.

indicators.justification:
The official UAE Website mention that Dubai's law (1) No. 26 of 2015 assures freedom and access to information, however there is no explicit mention in the law about that (2). However there is a draft guide mentioned in the same page, to access government information since 2017. The draft document (3) goals  complement the higher goals of the country, Vision 2021 and the UN's Sustainable Development Goals, it defines Open Data and Government information, with basic guidelines, what could be provided and what it cannot, ...etc but it does not provides a legal framework for access to information.

indicators.justification:
UAE company data is not available globally in UAE, only Abu Dhabi and Dubai publish some datasets. Dubai is the only one publishing in open data, however it's limited for non-commercial, personal use only. Visitors or users are not permitted to modify, distribute, publish or create derivative works for any public or commercial purposes according to the license (1).

The research did not find any products or services exist that use open company data to support due diligence.
